block.p: International

President Clinton renewed China's favored trade status and said he would no longer use trade to force China to improve human rights. [ Page A1. ] With the decision, economic interests won over America's self-image as the world's human rights advocate. [ A1. ]
International

President Clinton renewed China's favored trade status and said he would no longer use trade to force China to improve human rights. [ Page A1. ] With the decision, economic interests won over America's self-image as the world's human rights advocate. [ A1. ]

American companies say they are relieved that President Clinton has decided to keep China in the family of America's most favored trading nations. China, it seems, has become the fastest-growing market for some companies. [ D1. ]

The Justice Department settled an antitrust suit with a British glassmaker, preventing it from blocking American companies from doing business overseas. Japan, regarded as a possible target of similar suits, vigorously denounced the tactic. [ A1. ]
A senior Japanese cabinet official acknowledged that companies throughout the country had denied job opportunities to women during that country's four-year economic downturn. [ A9. ]
A deal has been completed to rescue the company that operates the tunnel between England and France. [ D4. ] Companies
Carter Hawley Hale has the potential to stage a remarkable turnaround, or it could fall back into bankruptcy. [ D1. ]
CBS Broadcast Group's president said the network would replace the stations that defected to Fox Broadcasting. [ D1. ]
Digital Equipment's chief financial officer resigned and will be replaced by the company's controller. [ D1. ]
Representative Jack Brooks said he would introduce a bill to modify the law that exempts insurers from antitrust rules. [ D5. ]
The software maker Computer Associates stunned Wall Street by posting higher than expected sales and earnings for its fiscal year and fourth quarter. [ D4. ]
The parent of Western Union Financial Services has spurned a $430 million offer by the First Data Corporation. [ D4. ]
Shares of Boeing Company rose $2.50, to $47, after a published report said the company was about to receive a $5 billion order for more than 50 jetliners from China. [ D4. ]
A battery-powered Geo Metro has driven 214 miles without a recharge. The car runs on nickel metal hydride batteries, which are more often found in laptop computers. [ D4. ] Markets
Mutual fund investors seem less alarmed about interest rates, and withdrawals from bond funds have slowed. But there are only limited indications that they are willing to risk more cash. [ D2. ]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed, with the long bond bouncing up and down before ending lower. [ D5. ]
Stocks barely moved as traders headed into the Memorial Day weekend, but a few market leaders, like Philip Morris and Boeing, showed sharp swings. The Dow fell 1.84 points, to 3,753.46. [ D6. ]
The dollar finished mostly higher in global foreign exchange trading, aided by a technical rally that reversed a downward slide early in the day. [ D16. ]
Coffee prices continued to slide, and an index of 21 commodities retreated for the third consecutive day after reaching a three-and-a-half-year high on Monday. [ D16. ] The Economy
A bill was introduced in the House of Representatives to tighten the supervision of the derivatives activities of banks. [ D5. ] Today's Columns
A group of investors is betting that Stone & Webster, the engineering company that builds nuclear power plants, is poised for a turnaround. Market Place. [ D6. ]
Three longtime creative executives are forming a new advertising agency that they said would promulgate what they call "black and blue advertising." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D17. ]
